author: Fred Mawer For Mail On Sunday
title: The Crafty Traveller: Don’t blow your budget before you even leave... here's how to avoid pricey airport parking charges, trains, and restaurants
text:
6 shares 4
View
comments
Flights, accommodation, eating out, entertainment... most of us analyse these costs carefully on overseas holidays.
But we often overlook another major expense before we have even jetted off – getting to and through the airport.
Here are some ways to avoid paying over the odds on airport-related costs.
Many of us spend a large sum of money before we even leave the airport on outlets such as train fares, parking fees, airport hotels and dining out
Trains
Book ahead online, and research alternative options to airport express services.
For the Stansted Express , online deals include 50 per cent off the standard fare if you book 30 days or more ahead.
For the Gatwick Express , booking online is at least ten per cent cheaper, and 35 per cent less with a Web Duo deal covering two passengers travelling together, and 50 per cent less with a 4-for-2 deal.

The Crafty Traveller: Package holidays are in rude health... Even so, Thameslink services from Central London to Gatwick – which can be as quick as the Gatwick Express – will work out cheaper.
The Heathrow Express is currently offering an online Duo Saver deal, saving a couple £20 on a return trip – and, since the spring, children under 16 have travelled on the trains for free.
However, for a couple it still works out at least £9.60 less to take the slower Heathrow Connect Paddington-Heathrow service, while for a family or couple it’s much cheaper using the Underground’s Piccadilly line.
On longer train journeys, travelling at peak times to/ from the airport can be exorbitant. In which case, look at much more affordable coach options with National Express .
Parking prices at airports vary by up to 50 per cent depending on how far in advance you book
Parking
You can often make considerable savings by booking well in advance.
For example, for a week’s parking at Manchester Airport’s Long Stay Terminal 2 car park, I’ve been Quote: d £79.99 booking two days ahead; £69.99 three days ahead; £59.99 a fortnight ahead; £54.99 a month ahead; and £39.99 four months ahead.
The pricing pattern is similar at Luton Airport, though not at all airport car parks.
Even if you haven’t booked long ahead, do still pre-book to avoid paying massively dearer turn-up rates. You normally need to book at least 24 or 48 hours ahead to get a good advance booking deal.
Check which car parks and booking agents have the best rates using comparison website airport-parking-shop.co.uk .
Off-airport car parks can be cheaper (stick to ones with Park Mark status), but not always, and given that bus transfers from them can be longer, small savings over using an official on-airport car park are not necessarily worth it.
If you need parking, using an airport hotel can be particularly appealing, as stay-and-park packages can be great value
Hotels
Got an early-morning flight? Staying the night before at an airport hotel can make sense.
Again, book as far ahead as possible to get the best rates.
For example, for most nights in November, Premier Inn currently has rooms for under £40 at its London Heathrow Airport (Bath Road) and London Gatwick Airport (North Terminal) hotels, and at the Hampton by Hilton London Gatwick, conveniently joined to the North Terminal, rates are a reasonable £71 B&B.
If you need parking, using an airport hotel can be particularly appealing, as stay-and-park packages can be great value.
Holiday Extras is good for comparing airport hotel rates, with and without parking.
Get the airport in good time to avoid the need to pay for fast-track privileges, which can add up if you are in a large party
Security
Some airports offer fast-track privileges through security for a fee.
At Luton, Liverpool and Bristol airports, fast track costs £5 if you haven’t pre-booked, £3 to £3.95 if you have.
The charges are per person, so quickly add up for a family. To avoid the need to use fast track, arrive at the airport in good time.
The above airports, and some others, charge an extortionate £1 for resealable transparent bags to take liquids through security – bring your own.
Instead of pricier alternatives, opt for a sandwich from food outlets such as M&S Simply Food
Food
Tempting but costly restaurants at the major airports have proliferated – such as a Jamie’s Italian at Gatwick North, and Gordon Ramsay’s Plane Food at Heathrow’s Terminal 5.
Save by buying sandwiches at an M&S Simply Food airport outlet – note that restrictions through security apply to liquids, not food.
Some Heathrow restaurants are running ‘kids eat free’ offers until September 6: see heathrow.com/shops-and-restaurants/special-offers/kids-eat-free .
